Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Individualized PEEP in Thoracoscopic Lobectomy

Background: This study investigates the impact of individualized positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) titrated to maximum dynamic lung compliance on postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) in patients undergoing video-assisted thoracoscopic lobectomy.

Methods: Conducted as a single-center, randomized controlled trial, 100 patients scheduled for thoracoscopic lobectomy were randomized to receive either individualized PEEP guided by maximum dynamic pulmonary compliance or a fixed PEEP of 5 cm H2O. The primary outcome was the incidence of PPCs within seven days post-surgery, defined by the European Perioperative Clinical Outcome criteria. Secondary outcomes included PEEP, Cdyn, PaO2, serum concentrations of IL-6 and TNF-α, and length of hospital stay. Randomization was achieved using SPSS-generated sequences with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes. Patients, data managers, and statistical analysts were blinded.

Results: Between October 2022 and October 2023, 100 patients were randomized: 50 to the individualized PEEP group and 50 to the control group. Analysis included all participants. PPCs occurred in 20% of the individualized group versus 38% in the control group (risk difference, -18.0%; 95% CI, -35.4% to -0.6%; p = 0.047). The optimal PEEP in the individualized group was 9.04 ± 1.83 cm H2O. Serum IL-10 was higher and IL-1β lower in the individualized group (p < 0.05). No significant differences in PaO2 or TNF-α were observed. No severe adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: Individualized PEEP based on dynamic compliance significantly reduces PPCs compared to fixed PEEP, suggesting a beneficial role in thoracoscopic lobectomy.

Trial registration: ChiCTR2100048201.

Funding: Not specified.
